div.head: Sixty-Two Erroneous Views from Toh 113 Glossary

item.p: A. Eighteen views based upon the past, which are comprised of:
Two views that everything is eternal as a result of clairvoyantly remembering as far back as thirty intermediate kalpas:
(1) The belief that the self is eternal, and (2) the belief that the world is eternal.
Two views that everything is eternal as a result of clairvoyantly remembering rebirths as far back as sixty to ninety intermediate kalpas:
(3) The belief that the self is eternal, and (4) the belief that the world is eternal.
Four views of annihilation:

(5) The belief that apart from Mahābrahmā the world and the other devas are impermanent on seeing clairvoyantly the demise of other devas in his paradise; (6) the belief that devas in the desire realm who become angered are impermanent but other devas are eternal, on seeing clairvoyantly the demise of angered devas in in the Trāyastriṃśa paradise; (7) the belief that devas in the desire realm who are distracted by pleasures are impermanent but other devas are eternal, on seeing clairvoyantly the demise of devas in in the Trāyastriṃśa paradise because in their enjoyment of pleasures they forget to eat; and (8) the belief that the four elements are impermanent but mind and mental events are eternal, on seeing clairvoyantly the cessation of the elements in the formless realm.
Four beliefs in the existence and non-existence of limits:

(9) The belief that self and the world have a limit, on seeing clairvoyantly from the hells to the four dhyānas only; (10) the belief that self and the world have no limit, on seeing clairvoyantly as far as certain boundaries and deciding there is more beyond; (11) the belief that there is and there is not a limit, on seeing clairvoyantly the limit of the human world but not that of the world of Brahmā, and (12) the belief that there neither is nor is not a limit, on seeing the world of Brahmā and not being able to see that there is a limit or that there is not a limit.
Four beliefs of not abandoning the view of immortality when it is argued against:

(13) because of little wisdom, (14) because of not being trained in their tradition, (15) because of being trained but (not?) having definite knowledge, and (16) because of being proud thinking there is no answer to the questions they are asked.
The beliefs that there are no causes on the basis of dhyāna and knowledge:

(17) The belief that all worlds arise without a cause; because having left the existence that is a state of meditation without perception, they do not see that there is a subtle basis and believe that senses arise from nothing and also because they cannot see the atoms that combine to create the world, and (18) the belief that there is no cause because the wind and clouds appear spontaneously.
B. Forty-four views based upon the future, which are comprised of:
Sixteen beliefs that there are perceptions:

(19) The self has perception with form perception (delete "perception"?); (20) the self has perception without form; (21) the self has perception that has form and is formless; and (22) the self has perception that has neither form nor is formless. (23) The self has perception that has a limit; (24) the self has perception that has no limit; (25) the self has perception that both has and does not have a limit; and (26) the self has perception that is neither with nor without limit. (27) The self has perception that has bliss; (28) the self has perception that has suffering; (29) the self has perception that has both bliss and suffering; and (30) the self has perception that has neither bliss nor suffering. (31) The self has a single perception; (32) the self has various perceptions; (33) the self has small perception; and (34) the self has vast perception.
Eight beliefs in the absence of perception:

(35) The self that has form has no perception, like hair and nails; (36) a self without form has no perception, like space; (37) that which is both has no perception; and (38) that which is neither has no perception. (39) The self that has a limit has no perception; (40) a self without limit has no perception; (41) that which is both has no perception; and (42) that which is neither has no perception.
Eight beliefs in there being neither existence nor non-existence of perception:
Seven nihilistic beliefs:

(51) The humans in the desire realm have no previous or future lives, suffer while alive, and after death there is oblivion. It is the same for (52) the devas of the desire realm; (53) the devas of the form realm; (54) the devas of the formless realm of infinite space; (55) the devas of the formless realm of infinite consciousness; (56) the devas of the formless realm of nothingness; and (57) the devas of the formless realm that is the summit of existence.
The belief in nirvāna:

(58) The devas of the desire realm have no previous or future life, but in this life they have the nirvāna of the pleasures of their existence. It is the same for (59) the first dhyāna’s meditation on samādhi, and (60) for the second dhyāna, (61) the third dhyāna, and (62) the fourth dhyāna.

div.head: The Three Hundred and Sixty Classes of Heretical Texts and their Teachers
div.p: Fifth, the three hundred and sixty classes of heretical texts and their teachers may also be presented in terms of the eleven categories (13.1.2.5). On this [it says in the root verses]:

q.p: And there are eleven specific categories of heretical texts.

div.p: There are three hundred notions concerning the limits of present time (da ltar gyi mtha’ la rtog pa sum brgya), starting with the ten imitators (mgo snyoms pa bcu), which, along with the [aforementioned] eighteen notions concerning the limits of past time and the forty-two notions concerning the limits of future time, add up to three hundred and sixty.
Among them, first of all, those concerning the limits of present time [may be subsumed in the following eleven categories]:

item.p: The ten imitators which include: (i) conventional extremists who imitate the pious attendants (nyan thos la mgo snyoms pa mu rtegs tha snyad pa); (ii) consumers (bhakṣaka, za ba pa) who imitate the hermit buddhas; (iii) atomists (sūkṣmaka, phra ba pa) who imitate the Cittamātrins, (iv) great atomists (mahāsukṣamaka, phra ba chen po) who imitate the Mādhyamika, (v) ritualists (rigs byed pa) who imitate Action Tantra, (vi) practitioners (rigs spyod pa) who imitate Conduct Tantra, (vii) yogins (rigs sbyor ba) who imitate Union Tantra, (viii) practitioners of intense ascetic discipline (brtul zhugs cher spyod pa) who imitate Father Tantra, (ix) appraisers of spiritual triumph (jaimini, rgyal dpogs) who imitate Mother Tantras, and (x) acquirers of spiritual triumph (jayalabdha, rgyal thob pa) who imitate Non-dual Tantra. These [imitators] are held to number one hundred when subdivided according to the five material elements and the sensory elements associated with the five quidities. The source for this passage is Longchen Rabjam’s Padma dkar po, p. 357. Our text misreads ’byung ba lnga dang chen po lnga dang khams las las phye ba, but Padma dkar po offers the more accurate reading of ’byung ba lnga dang chen po lnga yi khams las phye ba. That said, the expression chen po lnga surely implies the five quidities (de tsam lnga) on which see below, p. XXX.

The nine propounding coherent eternalism (rtag pa ther zug dgu) which include: (i) those upholding eternalism in general (spyir rtag par ’dod pa), and in particular, (ii) those holding chance and mighty Īśvara to be an eternal creator (phyva dang dbang phyug byed pa po rtag par ’dod pa), (iii) those holding the words of the Vedas to be eternal (rig byed kyi tshig rtag par ’dod pa), (iv) those holding an inexpressible soul to be eternal (brjod du med pa’i bdag rtag par ’dod pa), (v) those holding objects of knowledge to be eternal (rig bya rtag par ’dod pa), (vi) those holding attributes to be eternal (yon tan rtag par ’dod pa), (vii) those holding primal matter and the soul to be eternal (gtso bdag rtag par ’dod pa), (viii) those holding the nine categories [of phenomena] to be eternal (tshig gi don dgu rtag par ’dod pa) and (ix) those holding states of knowledge to be eternal (rig pa’i gnas rtag par ’dod pa). These may number one hundred and one when each of them is appraised in terms of the following eleven aspects: (i) eternal nature (rtag pa’i rang bzhin), (ii) soul (bdag), (iii) primal matter (gtso bo), and in terms of its threefold modification (rnam ’gyur gsum), (iv) the objects of cognition (rig bya), (v) the process of cognition (rig byed), (vi) the states of cognition (rig yul), (vii) their activation (spyod tshul), (viii) their action (las), (ix) their generic state (spyi), (x) their interaction (’brel ba), and (xi) the force of their combined impact (’bad ’du’i shugs). The source for this passage is again Padma dkar po, pp. 357-358. Some of these key terms are discussed below, in the context of Sāṃkhya. There are some discrepancies between that source and our text and also the corresponding entry in Nordrang Orgyan 2008, p. 3840, regarding the way in which the eleven subcategories are tallied. Note also that our text reads ’grel pa for ’brel ba.

The six propounding irrationality (smyon par smra ba drug) who include: (i) the followers of Jaimini who would establish silence as a reason for the proof of omniscient beings; (ii) the Naiyāyika (rig pa can pa) who would establish that the attributes of the soul, including happiness and suffering, are objectifiable in all things in order to prove that the soul is present in all things; (iii) the Mīmāṃsika (spyod pa ba) who would establish that sound is uncreated in order to prove that it is eternal; (iv) the Digambara (nam mkha’i gos can) who would establish the fact that leaves die during the night and that peeled bark will wither in order to prove that wood is animate; (v) the Sāṃkhya (grangs can pa) who would establish the fact that bark which has been peeled will die as a reason in order to prove that matter is animate; and (vi) the Vaiśeṣika (bye brag pa) who would establish that living beings possess life in order to prove that the body of living beings is endowed with a soul. These may number eighteen since in terms of the understanding of compatible factors (sapakṣa, mthun phyogs) each seeks to prove that their (i) premise (dam bca’), (ii) reason (hetu, gtan tshigs) and (iii) example (upamā, dpe) are discernible. See Padma dkar po, p. 358.

The seven with faith in meditative concentration (sgom pa bsam gtan la dad pa bdun) who include: (i) the Bārhaspatya (phur bu pa) who meditate that even relative appearances are non-existent; (ii) the Sāṃkhya (grangs can pa) who meditate on emptiness devoid of modifications; (iii) the Saura (nyi ma pa) who meditate on emptiness by rejecting light; (iv) the followers of Jayadhara (dzA ya dha ri ba) who meditate with one-pointed non-conceptualization, regarding the six aspects of consciousness and their sense objects as defective; (v) the Vaiśeṣika (bye brag pa) who meditate with one-pointed non-recollection, regarding recollection as defective; (vi) the Śaiva (zhi ba pa) who meditate without distraction on the nature of mind, considering that all things are mind; and (vii) the Vaidika (rig byed pa), who meditate in a manner similar to space, having rejected all [dichotomies of] happiness and suffering, or of conceptualization and non-conceptualization. These may also number twenty-eight since each of them may be considered in terms of (i) the essential nature of their focus on meditative stability, (ii) their categories, (iii) their experiences, and (iv) their fruits. See Padma dkar po, pp. 358-359.

The six teachers propounding nihilism (chad par smra ba’i ston pa drug) who are the aforementioned teachers, starting with Purāṇakāśyapa. Their tenets may also be held to number thirty-two since they seek to understand: (i) past and future lives, (ii) actions, cases and results; (iii) release and liberation, and (iv) an indiscernible soul which does not move, by means of: (i) the single approach, (ii-iv) the three examples and (v-viii) the four modalities. The single approach (rgyu gcig) is so called because none of these is discerned within the perceptual range of one’s own sense faculties.

The three examples (dpe gsum) comprise: (i) the example of non-causation, which is the bursting forth of mushrooms on the grasslands; (ii) the example of non-fruition which is the scattering of dust by the wind; and (iii) the example of natural emergence which corresponds to the verse: ‘waterfalls at sunrise, peas that are round, thorns with tips that are long and sharp, princesses who are lovely to behold—all these appear naturally, uncreated by anyone!’ A similar quotation also occurs in the Grub mtha mdzod, p. 54, on which see Barron 2007: 65; and also in the gSang snying spyi don yid kyi mun sel, p. 30.

The four modalities (tshul bzhi) comprise: (i) the modality through which happiness, suffering and so forth exist here in the present life, although there are no past or future lives; (ii) the modality through which suddenly arising corporeal forms are naturally present of their own accord when they take shape, even though the soul and primal matter are [supposed to be] unchanging through past and future lives; (iii) the modality through which living beings are formed from the suddenly arising material compositions of the five material elements, including earth, that enable awareness to develop; Our text appears to be corrupt in reading la sogs for sa sogs, and grol ba grub pa’i tshul for ’gro ba grub pa’i tshul. See Padma dkar po, p. 359. and (iv) the modality through which, when one understands the fact that there is no cause and effect, since beings are not released through the austerities of refining the path, but they are released naturally, there will be no need to rely on hardships in this life and so the textual tradition of the Lokāyatika will not be rendered meaningless—when beings pass away, they all abide in an identical state of release. Accordingly, various sources (ra ma ra rnams) assert: See Padma dkar po, pp. 359-360.

lg.l: Owing to the three examples and the four modalities,
All things are definitively established in the single approach.
Since entities are entirely without cause,
How could the release of liberation be possible!

item.p: The six ministers (blon po drug) including the masters: (i) Abhayaprāpta (’jigs med thob); (ii) Somabhāskarakīrti (nyi zla grags), (iii) Sāraprāpta (snying po thob); (iv) Satyaprāpta (bden pa thob); (v) Jñānavāda (shes par smra); and (vi) Maṅgalaprāpta (bkra shis thob). The Sanskrit names given here are all unattested reconstructions. On this passage, see Padma dkar po, p. 360. They claim that whatever is active and present in the world is true, contrary to the Buddhists and the extremists. For this reason, they esteem six repositories of knowledge (rig pa’i mdzod drug), namely: the planets, the constellations, the seasons, the gods, topics of scrutiny (brtag pa’i gnas) and rituals (srid bsrung ba); and they emphasize positive and negative ideas with regard to the present alone. In terms of their practical application, these six fields [of knowledge] may be reduced to three. That is to say, there are astrologers who disclose the positive and negative impacts of the planets, constellations, and calendar days; kings who protect their subjects by knowing the laws that derive from the lineage of universal monarchs and so forth who maintain the righteousness (chos lugs) of the gods; merchants who engage in distinctive topics of scrutiny, of horses, elephants, oceans and so forth; priests who differentiate matters of state, such as [the prospects for] victory and defeat; and ordinary citizens who engage in their seasonal livelihood. But these may be subsumed in the three categories of kings, scientists and citizens, so that the priests, Our text (Sichuan ed. p. 697) and Padma dkar po, p. 360 both read blon po (“ministers”) for mdun na ‘don (“priests”) at this point. merchants and ordinary citizens are rolled into one. Their fields of knowledge may also number thirty-six since there are six common [fields of knowledge] and then these six may be [differently] understood by kings, ministers [or priests], scientists, merchants, and ordinary citizens. This would surely engender an enumeration of thirty rather than thirty-six. Nordrang Orgyan 2008: 3841 is similarly perplexed.

The four types of incidental extremists (zhar byung gi mu stegs bzhi), including: (i) the aspirant (mos pa), (ii) the attached (chags pa), (iii) the distracted (yengs pa), and (iv) the perceptive who are being distracted (gYeng ba’i ’du shes can). They all hold that by indulging in the happiness of this life they will attain liberation. They are four in number because they respectively: aspire to the desirable attributes of the senses, they are attached to them, they have been distracted by them and they are being distracted by them.

There are six exponents of sophistry (tarka sde drug), namely: (i) those whose [rambling] reasoning resemble a breeze driving a donkey (ser bu bong ’ded gyi sde), (ii) those whose [absurd] reasoning resembles eating the skin and flesh of a wall (rtsig lpags sha zan gyi sde), (iii) those whose [incredible] reasoning resembles the sight of a fox’s head (va mgo re thong gi sde), (iv) those who are materialists (‘jig rten rgyan ’phen pa’i sde), (v) those who always deny causality (rgyu ’bras gtan med kyi sde), and (vi) those who espouse meaningless apathy (phyal pa don med kyi sde). These six modes derive from their [common belief in] the non-existence of causes. See Padma dkar po, p. 361.

The four false views regarding causes (rgyur lta ba bzhi), namely: (i) the false view of nature as a cause (rang bzhin rgyur lta ba); (ii) the false view of a creator [Brahmā divinity] as a cause (byed po rgyur lta ba); (iii) the false view of Īśvara as a cause (dbang phyug rgyur lta ba); and (iv) the false view of time as a cause (dus rgyur lta ba). These four are established as such because they derive from the false view of eternalism.

The two [pre-eminent] preceptors [propagating such views] (mkhan po gnyis), namely Śaṅkara (dung ’dzin), the master of the eternalists; and Bṛhaspati, the master of the nihilists. These two are respectively the primary [exponents] of eternalism and nihilism.
The Vedāntaupaniṣadika (rigs byed kyi mtha’ gsang ba pa) who are included among the Mīmāṃsika.

div.p: So it is that there are one hundred imitative philosophical systems (mgo snyoms pa’i grub mtha’ brgya), one hundred and one eternalist views (rtag pa ba’i brgya rtsa gcig), eighteen irrational views (smyon par smra ba’i bco brgyad), twenty-eight false views of meditators (bsam gtan pa’i nyi shu rtsa brgyad), thirty-six false views of [nihilistic] ministers (blon po drug gi sum cu rtsa drug), four incidental false views (zhar byung gi bzhi), six exponents of sophistry (tarka sde drug), four false views regarding causes (rgyur lta ba bzhi), two [primary] preceptors (mkhan po gnyis), and the Aupaniṣadika (gsang ba pa). Together these comprise the three hundred [false views] which depend on the limit of present time. This calculation of three hundred and sixty omits the fifth of the eleven categories, comprising the six teachers who espouse nihilism and their thirty-two views. That same group is also excluded from the list found in the source text, Padma dkar po, p. 361, presumably because the immediately following list of the thirty-six ministers is reckoned to subsume both.
